summary: This is a letter motion filed by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, requesting Judge Alison J. Nathan to quash a subpoena issued by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team to the administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP). The government argues the subpoena fails to meet the legal standards for relevance, admissibility, and specificity, and constitutes a fishing expedition.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case who issued the subpoena to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program that the government is seeking to quash.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case to whom the government's motion to quash the subpoena is addressed.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted the letter motion.

connections.description: The document references Witness-3 as one of the Minor Victims, indicating Maxwell is the accused perpetrator in the case.
The document references Accuser-2 as one of the Minor Victims, indicating Maxwell is the accused perpetrator in the case.

events.title: Pre-trial Conference
events.description: A conference where the defense sought to preclude the government from arguing that the Minor Victims' settlements with the EVCP reflect an endorsement of their claims.

events.title: EVCP Protocol Established
events.description: The protocol governing the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program was established, which is referenced in the defense's argument about victim bias.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The U.S. government filed a motion to quash Ghislaine Maxwell's subpoena to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP) administrator, arguing it fails legal standards.
The defense sought four categories of EVCP information: payment records, claim release forms, all material submitted by victims, and all communications.
The government argues the subpoena is a 'fishing expedition' and that the requested information is either already in the defense's possession or not relevant/admissible.
The document references 'Minor Victims' including 'Witness-3' and 'Accuser-2', and notes the court ordered that Witness-3 should not be referenced at trial as a victim.
The government contends that exploring EVCP materials at trial would confuse the jury and waste time, as the trial is not about the EVCP's adjudicative process.
